Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Landlord advocates strongly disputed the report’s conclusions.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Landlord advocates strongly disputed the report’s conclusions.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Tenant advocates took a very different view of the report. They said it correctly identifies problems with L.A. rent control and validates their demands for stronger limits.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Tenant advocates took a very different view of the report.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Tenant advocates have called for a 3% ceiling on annual rent hikes and elimination of the 2% surcharge for landlords who provide gas and electricity.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Tenant advocates took a very different view of the report.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.
Document Sources.Source Justification: LAist obtained the report through a public records request.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The report makes some recommendations on how the city could change its formula for determining annual rent increase limits:
Document Sources.Source Justification: LAist obtained the report through a public records request.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The report notes that because L.A. has a 3% floor on annual increases — even in years when the consumer price index is lower — landlords have often been allowed to raise rents above inflation.
Document Sources.Source Justification: LAist obtained the report through a public records request.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Daniel Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles pointed to recent data from the National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners, concluding that California landlords earn 7 cents of profit on average for every dollar of rent.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Daniel Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “What [the report] is trying to do is make a PR effort to lay the groundwork to chip away at what little ability landlords have in L.A. to be able to raise rents and be able to keep up with their costs,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Daniel Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He said the report takes a macroeconomic view of the city’s rental market, but fails to capture the unique struggles facing many small landlords.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Daniel Yukelson with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization,” said Christina Boyar, a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The report shows that rent costs exceeding what tenants can pay is a primary cause of homelessness,” Boyar said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Daniel Flaming, president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report, said he didn’t have a good answer for why the report was kept under wraps.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I think when it's a politically contentious issue, there are attempts to manage the conversation,” Flaming said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: In an email reacting to the Economic Roundtable report, Soto-Martínez told LAist, “As we await the finalized version of this report, it’s heartening to see so much data supporting the policy changes that renters have been demanding — especially when it comes to preventing excessive rent increases that can devastate working families.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the council members who requested the report be commissioned

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Sharon Sandow, a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department, told LAist last week the document was still a “draft report,” and they didn't have a specific date lined up for its release.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a spokesperson for the L.A. Housing Department

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Economic Roundtable, the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study, submitted its report to the L.A. Housing Department.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: the nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a trade group for property owners

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Christina Boyar, a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a legal fellow with Public Counsel

Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition
